question_chart_description: Circle with center A. Point B is on the right edge. Point C is on the bottom-left edge, creating a wide obtuse central angle BAC labeled 100°.
question: In the figure above, point <math><mi>A</mi></math> is the center of the circle, and the measure of angle <math><mi>B</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math><mn>100</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of minor arc <math><mover><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>⌢</mo></mover></math>?
explanation: The measure of a minor arc is defined as the measure of its corresponding central angle. Since angle BAC is the central angle ($100^{circ}$) that intercepts arc BC, the measure of minor arc BC is also $100^{\circ}$.

explanation_chart_description: The same circle with the central angle BAC shown as obtuse. The minor arc BC is highlighted in red and labeled as 100°.
score_improvement_tip: Remember: Central Angle = Minor Arc Measure. If the vertex of the angle is at the center of the circle, the angle and the arc it 'eats' are equal in degrees.
